title: 109_hr4867
content: The "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006" establishes a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. It also addresses applicable laws, requirements, and the availability of funds for the self-determination process. The Congress acknowledges past efforts by Presidents Bush and Clinton to address Puerto Rico's political status through referendums and task forces. President George W. Bush adopted Executive Order 13183 and amended it in 2003 to require the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status to issue reports every two years on progress towards determining Puerto Rico's ultimate status. In 2005, the Task Force recommended that Congress organize a federally sanctioned plebiscite for Puerto Ricans to vote on remaining a territory or pursuing a path towards permanent status. The people of Puerto Rico can choose to pursue a permanent nonterritorial status or remain a United States territory. If they opt for a nonterritorial status, there should be a subsequent plebiscite to choose between two options. If they choose to remain a territory, periodic plebiscites should be held to keep Congress informed. Periodic plebiscites should occur to keep Congress informed of the people's wishes as long as a territorial status continues. Federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between continuing the existing territorial status or pursuing a path towards a permanent nonterritorial status. Instructions on the ballot will specify that only one option should be marked, and ballots with multiple options marked will not be counted. If the majority in the first plebiscite favors continued territorial status, further procedures will be followed. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years if the majority vote favors continued territorial status. If the majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite will be conducted under a different procedure. The State Elections Commission in Puerto Rico will conduct a plebiscite offering two options: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. Instructions on the ballot specify that only one option should be marked, and ballots with multiple choices will not be counted. If a majority vote in the first plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, the next plebiscite must be held by the 111th Congress, but no later than December 31, 2009. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, the next plebiscite must be held within 2 years after the certification of the majority vote. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. All Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite held under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to this Act. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules for the plebiscites. Eligible voters under electoral laws can participate in the plebiscites. (d) Eligibility to vote in plebiscites under this Act includes all eligible voters under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and all US citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet the State Elections Commission requirements. They can request an absentee ballot. The State Elections Commission certifies the results of each plebiscite. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission certifies plebiscite results to the President and Congress. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status submits a report detailing measures for implementing the chosen nonterritorial status option. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all required plebiscites are completed, the Secretary of the Treasury can allocate up to $5,000,000 from funds provided to Puerto Rico for plebiscite expenses. This includes voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status.
